title: Créteil
text:
Créteil () is a <a href="Communes%20of%20France">commune</a> in the southeastern suburbs of <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="%C3%8Ele-de-France">Île-de-France</a>. It is located from the <a href="Kilometre%20Zero">centre of Paris</a>. Créteil is the "<a href="pr%C3%A9fecture">préfecture</a>" (capital) of the <a href="Val-de-Marne">Val-de-Marne</a> <a href="Departments%20of%20France">department</a> as well as the seat of the <a href="Arrondissement%20of%20Cr%C3%A9teil">Arrondissement of Créteil</a>. The city is, moreover, the seat of a <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Cr%C3%A9teil">Roman Catholic diocese</a> and of one of France's 30 nationwide "académies" (districts) of the <a href="French%20Ministry%20of%20Education">Ministry of National Education</a>.
Name.
The name Créteil was recorded for the first time as Cristoilum in the <a href="martyrology">martyrology</a> written by a <a href="monk">monk</a> named <a href="Usuard">Usuard</a> in 865. The name "Cristoilum" is made of the <a href="Celtic%20languages">Celtic</a> word "ialo" (meaning "clearing, glade", "place of") suffixed to a pre-Latin radical "crist-" whose meaning is still unclear. Some believe "crist" is a Celtic word meaning "ridge", a cognate of <a href="Latin">Latin</a> "crista" and modern French "crête", in which case the meaning of "Cristoilum" would be "clearing on the ridge" or "place on the ridge." A more traditional etymology was that "crist" referred to <a href="Jesus%20Christ">Jesus Christ</a>, due to the very ancient presence of Christianity in Créteil and the veneration of <a href="Agoard%20and%20Aglibert">Saint Agoard and Agilbert of Créteil</a>, martyred in Créteil around AD 400.
Geography.
Créteil is a city in the south-eastern suburbs of Paris. It is watered by the <a href="Marne%20%28river%29">Marne</a> river which carries out its last loop before the junction with the <a href="Seine">Seine</a> at the Charenton-le-Pont. The area is an alluvial plain eroded by the action of the Marne and the Seine. Bordering communes include <a href="Maisons-Alfort">Maisons-Alfort</a>, <a href="Saint-Maur-des-Foss%C3%A9s">Saint-Maur-des-Fossés</a>, <a href="Bonneuil-sur-Marne">Bonneuil-sur-Marne</a>, <a href="Limeil-Br%C3%A9vannes">Limeil-Brévannes</a>, <a href="Valenton">Valenton</a>, <a href="Choisy-le-Roi">Choisy-le-Roi</a> and <a href="Alfortville">Alfortville</a>.
Climate.
The climate in this area has mild differences between highs and lows, and there is adequate rainfall year-round. According to the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20Climate%20Classification">Köppen Climate Classification</a> system, Créteil has a <a href="marine%20west%20coast%20climate">marine west coast climate</a>, abbreviated "Cfb" on climate maps.
History.
Some rare flints from the <a href="Palaeolithic">Palaeolithic</a> age are still being found in modern times in the area. It is, however, a two-<a href="ton">ton</a>, <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>-era polishing machine that is the prehistoric pride of Créteil. The first documents referring to Créteil are from the <a href="Merovingian">Merovingian</a> era, when it was known as "Vicus Cristoilum"' The name comes from the prefix "crist" and "oilum". These two terms are thought to be <a href="Gaulish%20language">Gallic</a>: "clearing" for "oilum" and "ridge" for "crist". The "clearing" of the "ridge" of the Mont-Mesly is on the road connecting Paris and Sens (Trunk Road 19 today). In 1406, the place name "Créteil" makes its appearance after successive deformations from "Cristoill" (1278), "Cristeuil", "Cresteul" then "Creteuil".
During the <a href="French%20Wars%20of%20Religion">French Wars of Religion</a> (1567), the <a href="Huguenots">Huguenots</a> plundered the church and burned the local charters. New disorders in 1648 forced the evacuation of the inhabitants of Créteil. The end of <a href="Louis%20XIV">Louis XIV</a>'s reign was marked by a great food shortage throughout the whole of France after a terrible winter in 1709 that resulted in 69 recorded deaths in Créteil. Registers of grievances from the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a> in 1789 mention Créteil 15 times.
At the beginning of the 18th century, construction of the first middle-class "Parisian" houses began. In 1814, the east of Créteil was taken by Russian troops. The bridge which spans the Marne between Creteil and Saint-Maur-des-Fossés was inaugurated on 9 April 1841, replacing an ancient ferry.
The <a href="Franco-Prussian%20War">Franco-Prussian War</a> of 1870 was particularly cruel for Créteil. The borough was plundered and left in ruins by the Prussians, while the nearby battle of Mont-Mesly on 30 November 1870, left 179 dead. Créteil gave up its pastoral character after World War II. The population subsequently rose from 13,800 in 1954 to 30,654 in 1962.
L'<a href="Abbaye%20de%20Cr%C3%A9teil">Abbaye de Créteil</a> or Abbaye group was a utopian artistic and literary community founded during 1906 named after the Créteil Abbey near to where some members lived and where the group held meetings. At the time Créteil was still mostly pastoral, some of which remains in the forested parkland of the riverside district on and around Ile Sainte-Catherine. 
Although the group was short-lived, disbanding by 1908, it attracted artists, writers and philosophers to become associated with the <a href="Symbolist">Symbolist</a> and <a href="Futurist">Futurist</a> movements such as <a href="Filippo%20Tommaso%20Marinetti">Filippo Tommaso Marinetti</a>, author of the <a href="Futurist%20Manifesto">Futurist Manifesto</a>, and <a href="Constantin%20Br%C3%A2ncu%C8%99i">Constantin Brâncuși</a>. 
In 1965, the city became a Préfecture of the new department of the "Val-de-Marne".
The lake.
Créteil Lake began as a gypsum and gravel quarry. Once the <a href="groundwater">groundwater</a> was reached, forming deep ponds, the quarry was abandoned and allowed to fill with water. The lake area is now a popular recreational site attracting fishermen, boaters, wind surfers, etc...
Health.
As of 1 January 2006, 27 <a href="pharmacy">pharmacies</a>, about 60 dentists, about 60 general practitioners, 10 <a href="pediatrician">pediatrician</a>s, and a half-dozen ophthalmologists and dermatologists constitute the general medical staff of the city.

Primary and secondary schools.
Public schools:
Private schools:
Universities.
The city hosts <a href="Paris%2012%20Val%20de%20Marne%20University">Paris 12 Val de Marne University</a>, officially the Paris-Est Créteil Val-de-Marne University, founded in 1970. Previously known as Université Paris 12 Val de Marne or Université Paris XII, the university serves more than 30,000 students and consists of seven units of formation and research (UFR), namely law, administration, literature, medicine, business & management, educational sciences and technological sciences.
Transport.
Créteil is served by four stations on <a href="Paris%20M%C3%A9tro%20Line%208">Paris Métro Line 8</a>: <a href="Cr%C3%A9teil%20-%20L%27%C3%89chat%20%28Paris%20M%C3%A9tro%29">Créteil – L'Échat</a>, <a href="Cr%C3%A9teil%20-%20Universit%C3%A9%20%28Paris%20M%C3%A9tro%29">Créteil – Université</a>, <a href="Cr%C3%A9teil%20-%20Pr%C3%A9fecture%20%28Paris%20M%C3%A9tro%29">Créteil – Préfecture</a> and the newly opened (in 2011) <a href="Pointe%20du%20Lac%20%28Paris%20M%C3%A9tro%29">Pointe du Lac</a>.
Sport.
<a href="US%20Cr%C3%A9teil-Lusitanos">US Créteil-Lusitanos</a>, founded in 1936, is the city's <a href="association%20football">football</a> club. They currently play in <a href="National%20Championship">National Championship</a> (3rd division) and their home stadium is <a href="Stade%20Dominique%20Duvauchelle">Stade Dominique Duvauchelle</a>.
